phrases: Pink cherry blossoms, a blue sky, and white clouds.
There is nothing like eating rice balls under cherry blossom trees.
Sis, give me one more rice ball!
Um, fish flakes, and a chicken nugget, too!
but I think I like it like this.
It is not so crowded, so you can view them in peace.
I wonder if Rei has arrived in Yamagata yet.
I bet this is the best time to see them over there, too.
They wear armor and kimonos and hold it in a big park, right?
I bet it looks beautiful under cherry blossom trees.
Cherry blossoms in full bloom, the beautiful blue sky, green mountains...
It is just like I said.
I am not cut out for outdoor festivals.
On top of that, I am already feeling shameful
because I had straight losses at the Lion King Tournament and could not bring the match here.
Just go and let everyone cheer you up!
I did not mean that kind of cheering up, okay?
This lonely melody echoing through an empty train station!
From the City of Shogi, Tendou, Let us Get a Master!
What could I say to apologize?
They are all so kind that I know they would never blame me.
But that makes it more painful.
I would rather have them berate me.
What are you going to do about this rain?
That being said, I am being berated five seconds after getting here!
Here, hand out towels to the Pawns.
It is a new recipe from the Shiono Club.
And I was going to make a bundle selling the new product.
- But with this rain, it is a wash-out! - I am really sorry.
You were born to wear that, Kiddo!
He is like the daimyou, Shingen himself!
Like a full-sized Boys' Festival doll!
You have touched this old man's heart!
So where is your opponent, Yokomizo?
And he is like, um... Kobayakawa...
Hey, what is with that obscure lineup?
42nd Tendou Cherry Blossom Festival Human Shogi
42nd Tendou Cherry Blossom Festival Human Shogi
And now, Yokomizo 7th-Dan has the first move.
I forgot that a Lance moved up!
In Human Shogi, there is a rule, or goal rather, to move all of the pieces.
It is a different type of fight, so it is easy to miss something.
A move that takes advantage of his opponent's error!
In the 42nd Human Shogi game, the winner after 96 moves
You are saying it on purpose, Mr. Hanaoka!
Next up is the 100 Move event.
Chairman, Nikaidou, Okuyasu and I are participating.
Chairman, you are in the program, so you cannot run away!
But, I... My stomach is kind of hurting.
I heard you from the hallway excitedly talking about having Yonezawa beef tonight.
All of the participants are looking forward to beating you, Chairman!
But I learned my lesson last year.
These people are unusually good players.
Especially the old folks who are in the club you formed, Shimada.
Even the old lady over there would open with a Castle like it is nothing!
I cannot finish the game in two hours!
My Yonezawa beef will get cold.
Mr. Tsujii was complaining about doing it last year.
In his greeting at the opening ceremony, he pulled a fast one.
Nice to meet you, people of Yamagata.
I did not think the locals would be that put off by him.
If Mr. Tsujii is on stage, he is going to say a pun.
Players, thank you for your cooperation.
Everyone, thank you for your patience.
It is the ever-popular 100 Moves event.
And here are our professional shogi players.
Okuyasu, get in front of the Shiono Club.
These people have come to beat you, Chairman.
Okay, how about if I go?
I am not going to hold back.
I would not have it any other way!
You are going to miss dinner tonight!
I would like to eat dinner, though.
I came all the way back home, so let us all eat together.
What do you think of Shimada 8th-Dan's hometown, Kiriyama 5th-Dan?
Have I met him somewhere before?
I am Izumida with the Yamagata Journal.
He did an article on Mr. Shimada.
Um, I really get the feeling that everyone here is a strong supporter of Mr. Shimada.
Shimada 8th-Dan's real hometown is more in the back regions of Yamagata.
seniors living by themselves get isolated in their homes in the winter because of the snow.
He was troubled by that, so he created the Shiono Shogi Club.
Twice a week, a bus goes around to all the seniors' houses to pick them up
and they play shogi on kotatsus at the community center.
While some play shogi, others cook non-perishable food for the group in large pots.
And when it is time to go home, they take with them the daily necessities or ingredients
they would asked for as a group, as he arranged to buy it for them.
Shimada 8th-Dan is trying to arrange for the elderly people to not feel isolated anymore.
Shimada 8th-Dan also made the arrangements to sell
the non-perishable food and sweets the Shiono Club makes to the train stations.
Most wonderful of all is how these activities have made the old folks so spry.
I did not mean to bend your ear.
I am glad you told me.
Mr. Shimada has been depressed lately.
He wonders how he can apologize to everyone regarding the Lion King Tournament.
But right now, seeing him smile like that,
I have been covering him all this time for the newspaper, so I have become totally enamored.
When Mr. Izumida said that and smiled, he seemed delighted.
That kind of made me happy too.
And that feeling somehow filled me with joy.
Here is bakke miso, rice balls, snow greens pickled in salt, and whale rice cakes.
And here are some frozen dried persimmons.
You guys are giving me so much again.
We are never going to change.
We are never going to change.
I have been rushing so much that I lost my head.
How many times do I go back to where I started?
Even from here on out, that feeling will not go away, but...
From the City of Shogi, Tendou, Let us Get a Master!
Guess I will start over again this year and work hard.
It is going to be scary, but you should pass through.
I am not sure what to do.
Is it about your next new creation, Grandpa?
I am trying to think of something that would be good for the summer,
but I am not getting any inspiration.
The Baked Crescents are great and have become the shop's signature sweet,
but if possible, I would like one more new showpiece.
Then the name and form should be easy for people to remember, and do not get tired of.
But will also keep for a few days so it would be good as a present.
Long-lasting is important too, but if it is baked, it will overlap with the Baked Crescents.
Maybe we can go with something that is fresh.
Like the strawberry daifuku, which does not have a long shelf life, but is popular.
I was surprised the first time, but it turned out well and caught on here.
So something like the strawberry daifuku with an unexpected filling
and if we can get a new flavor, that would be great.
Okay Hina, for example, what filling would make you happy?
I think putting whipped cream in Japanese-style sweets would kill the merit of them.
I just think that could be heresy.
But bean paste and whipped cream are delicious together!
You know, like cream mitsumame or cream red bean soup!
True, cream mitsumame is good with whipped cream on top.
You cannot help dropping in at Flower Garden or Mitsuhashi.
But sweets shops are traps, are not they?
Should we get a sweet treat before going home?
It is okay to splurge once in a while, right?
Look, the mitsumame is only 350 yen.
But I would want to put sweet beans on top, too.
So that would be anmitsu for 430 yen.
For the two of us, it would be 860 yen.
In that case, for another 100 yen, we can have it with cream!
But if we are going that far, another 50 yen would get us whipped cream!
If we are putting whipped cream on top, I would want apricots, too!
In the end, All the toppings
We spent 1,610 yen on just a snack!
I am going to get fat!
Even though I am always stingy to a fault...
With 1,610 yen, we could have bought 2.3 kg of chicken at 68 yen per 100 grams.
With 2.3 kg, we could have fed the family for five days!
This is our punishment for going without Momo.
Now we have got to be even more frugal this month.
Hey, do not get depressed over there!
I thought you were going to help me come up with a new idea!
What filling would you like in a rice cake?
We have got a genius here!
Calm down and we can think it through again.
A tasty filling for a daifuku.
First, red bean paste, of course.
Do not go too far from the Japanese confections!
If I went along with what you are saying, this would turn into a cake shop!
Do you kids actually hate Japanese sweets?
Sweet green paste, matcha cream, strawberry cream, chestnut...
Woman want this and that, and are so greedy.
The rice cakes are filled with different flavors of bean jam
and when put together, look like snowmen.
Puffy can also mean good fortune, and I used it twice to double the good luck!
Two flavors of bean jam in a set and they are cute, too.
Sweet green paste and whipped cream or sweet red bean paste and sweet potato...
You can make variations by changing just the inside.
It would be nice to change the flavors with the seasons.
Chestnut paste in the fall, strawberry cream in the spring...
I will tell Sada and the others about it tomorrow.
I thought up of a sweet, too.
Mom came up with the Baked Crescents, right?
I am the one who worked hard to make the prototype, the mold, and the finishing touches.
But the one who thought up the cute shape and name was your mom, Mikako.
Mikako loved cooking, loved Japanese sweets,
and would learn by watching others, then make different prototype sweets on her own.
I hope this Puffy-Puffy Daruma makes everyone happy, just like the Baked Crescents.
I cannot wait for everyone to try it.
Would you like to come over for dinner tonight?
It was raining, but still fun.
My mentor shared it with me.
He said he could not eat all of it, so offered me some.
That day, Kiriyama brought over all kinds of goodies from Yamagata.
Sis was thrilled the side dishes crossed the bridge and made it over to us.
We also enjoyed the Puffy-Puffy Daruma I came up with for dessert.
And this is still a secret, but if I can, I would like to make Japanese sweets for a living
and someday run the shop with Grandpa.
I am just pursuing the truth!
There are limits in making snap decisions, too!
As you can see, I am gathering natto.
But I was definitely a guy who can bring out the sun!
For next year's Human Shogi, I have decided that it is going to be sunny!
Do not miss the next episode of March Comes in Like a Lion!
